g.text: • URI and domain part of the RqP's email address must match
• provides an STS service that supports the Token Exchange extension of OAuth 2.0
• is registered at AS-RqP as a public or confidential client
• acts as a Relying Party in respect of the RqP's Identity Provider in order to obtain an access_token_with_user_claims
• is registered at AS-RO as a public or confidential client
• acts as a token propagator between the AS-RqP and AS-RO
• has set up the RS, registers the resources at the AS-RO and sets policies
• URI and domain part of the RO's email address must match
• provides an STS service that supports the Token Exchange extension of OAuth 2.0
1. Send an HTTP request to the resource URI with no access token
AS-RO generates the permission_ticket (a JWT with a random NONCE value in the sub claim)
and the resource_claims_token which is bound to the permission_ticket through the permission_ticket sub claim hash.
iss is the URI that identifies who issues the resource_claims_token
aud is the URI that identifies the requested resource
sub is the permission_ticket sub claim hash computed as Base64URL-Encode(SHA256(permission_ticket{sub})
exp, nbf are the standard JWT claims)
5. verify the resource parameter value — optional
AS-RqP generates the identity_claims_token with these claims:
iss is the URI that identifies who issues the identity_claims_token
aud identifies the target service and it is the iss claim value extracted from the actor_token
sub identifies the RqP by email address and was extracted from the access_token_with_user_claims
exp, nbf are the standard JWT claims
act{aud} is the the resource parameter value — optional
act{sub} is the sub value extracted from the actor_token
6. Return the identity_claims_token in the access_token parameter,
5. identity_claims_token{act{aud}} and the RO's email address URI must match — optional
AS-RO generates the access token with the RqP's email address sub claim
(though the RqP is not signed in, the client acts on behalf of RqP) and with the additional RPT claim:
permissions, all permissions granted by the authorization server
8. Return the RPT, optionally a refresh_token
9. Send an HTTP request to the resource URI with RPT
10. Return the HTTP response, typically with 200, 201 status code
